title: Research Projects
text:
Outbreak response analytics and decision-making:

Using compartmental modelling to quantify the impact of pharmaceutical and non-pharmaceutical interventions on the spread of an epidemic.
Estimating the growth rate, time-varying reproduction number, and real-time infections from epidemiological counts using Bayesian methods and workflows from available R tools like {EpiNow2}, {epinowcast}, {epidemia}, and {EpiEstim}.
Investigating how modelling impacts public health decision-making.
R package development (software engineering) for outbreak analytics; converting new/existing models and methods into reusable software.

Tools and pipelines for reproducible research.
Improving the practice of science and its communication.

title: Open-source Projects
text:
The following are open-source projects that I lead or contribute to:

epichains: a successor of bpmodels, which is an R package for analysing the distribution of the size and length of transmission chains.
EpiNow2: An R package to estimate the time-varying reproduction number, growth rate, and doubling time using a range of open-source tools and best practices.
epinowcast: An R package that provides flexible and efficient methods to gain situational awareness during outbreaks using currently available epidemiological observations and the reporting patterns of historical observations.
Epiverse Initiative: An initiative that aims provide an integrated, generalisable, and scalable community-driven software ecosystem for outbreak analytics.

Find my GitHub page here.
I also,

Review open source R code/packages for journals like the Journal of Open Source Software. Do reach out if you need my services.

title: Dr. James M. Azam
text:
Hi there, I am a Research Software Engineer at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, working on the Epiverse-TRACE Initiative, which is a project to develop and maintain R packages for providing reproducible analytics support during epidemics.
I am mainly interested in developing models and methods and accompanying software to improve our understanding of how interventions impact disease spread.


üë®‚Äçüíº: Develop and maintain R packages for modelling infectious disease outbreaks, including:

Simulating and analysing transmission chains ({bpmodels}, {epichains}),
Estimating the time-varying reproduction number, growth rate, and real-time epidemiological counts ({EpiNow2})
Nowcasting and forecasting epidemiological counts that are biased by delays in reporting ({epinowcast}).

üïê: Co-maintain the Carpentries course on Data Analysis and Visualization in R for Ecologists.



I have a PhD with a specialisation in outbreak response modelling and decision-making. I am interested in the development of models and methods to evaluate the impact of pharmaceutical and non-pharmaceutical interventions on the spread of infectious vaccine-preventable diseases. However, more broadly, I am interested in quantitative research that improves the health outcomes.
Additionally, I like contributing to and indulging in the literature on how to improve science, including science communication and science policy.



üìñ: Reading Regression and Other Stories.
üñ•: Learning how to apply Bayesian data analysis to infectious disease nowcasting and forecasting through the Statistical Rethinking book.



I am interested in working with you on a mathematical or statistical method/model that improves how we do outbreak analytics.
We can also discuss how to generalise it into a piece of software.
Please get in touch through any of my linked contacts. I‚Äôm basically everywhere and tend to answer promptly.

title: The sequence() function
text:
In the past, when I‚Äôve tried to generate sequences of numbers from each element of a vector, I‚Äôve used a combination of the lapply() or sapply() and seq_len() functions. In a recent refactoring exercise, a colleague, Hugo Gruson pointed me to the sequence() function, which does the same job but in a terse manner.
For example, the following code generates a sequence of numbers from each element of a vector:
unlist(sapply(c(1, 3, 2), function(x) seq_len(x)))

[1] 1 1 2 3 1 2
The sequence() function is a simple function that can be used to generate sequences of numbers from each element of a vector. It provides a more concise way to generate sequences of numbers from each element of a vector while providing control over the starting and ending values of the sequence and the intervals in-between.

title: The sequence() function
text:
Syntax

sequence(nvec, from = 1, to = 1, along.with = NULL)

For example, the following code generates a sequence of numbers from each element of a vector:

sequence(c(1, 3, 2))

[1] 1 1 2 3 1 2


By default, the from and to arguments are set to 1. The along.with argument is used to specify the length of the sequence.

title: The sequence() function
text:
Example

sequence(c(1, 3, 2))

[1] 1 1 2 3 1 2


Beyond the defaults, the from and to arguments can be used to specify the starting and ending values of the sequence. The along.with argument can be used to specify the length of the sequence.

sequence(c(1, 3, 2), from = 2, to = 5)

[1] 2 2 3 4 2 3


In the above example, the sequence starts at 2 and ends at 5. The along.with argument is used to specify the length of the sequence.

title: The sequence() function
text:
Note



You may know about seq(), seq_len(), and seq_along(), but have you ever heard of sequence()?
I am inspired by Ma√´lle Salmon‚Äôs Useful R functions series to share useful R functions that help me to write terse code as I come across them.
In the past, when I‚Äôve tried to generate sequences of numbers from each element of a vector, I‚Äôve used a combination of the unlist(), lapply() and seq_len() functions.
my_vec <- c(1, 3, 2)
my_vec_sequence <- unlist(lapply(my_vec, seq_len))
my_vec_sequence

[1] 1 1 2 3 1 2
Recently, I was pointed to the sequence() function, which performs the same operation in a terse way.
The sequence() function is a simple function that can be used to generate sequences of numbers from each element of a vector. It provides control over the starting and ending values of the sequence and the intervals to be used.

title: The sequence() function
text:
Syntax

sequence(nvec, from = 1, to = 1, along.with = NULL)

title: The sequence() function
text:
Examples
Let‚Äôs use sequence() to generate a sequence of numbers from each element of a vector. Note that by default, the from and to arguments are set to 1. The along.with argument is used to specify the length of the sequence.

my_seq <- sequence(c(1, 3, 2))
my_seq

[1] 1 1 2 3 1 2


Beyond the defaults, the from and to arguments can be used to specify the starting and ending values of the sequence. Let‚Äôs generate a sequence from the vector c(1, 3, 2), starting at 2 and ending at 5 for each element.

my_seq <- sequence(c(1, 3, 2), from = 2, to = 5)
my_seq

[1] 2 2 3 4 2 3
